channel.title: John's Two Cents
channel.description: Recent content on John's Two Cents

item.title: How to fix TPM device detected but connection cannot be established
item.description: This issue crossed my path after installing VMWare ESXi on a brand new server. After logging for the first time I got a little notice that said: TPM device detected but a connection could not be established. With security in min this is something that you can’t leave like this so I started a little search and I ended up with the following solution. Bare in mind, the following solution is only tested with Dell servers as I haven’t experienced this with other brands that I use, like Lenovo.

item.title: Review of the Lenovo GO ANC headset
item.description: While the pandemic was ongoing we all switched from working at the office to working at home, todays evolution is more leaning to the hybrid working model. While I like going to the office again everyday a lot of colleagues still work more at home and that means: “Teams meetings”. While at work we use the Jabra headset the comfort isn’t all that well, because of that I got myself this more luxurious and comfortable headset.

item.title: Dall-E aka artificial intelligent painting
item.description: Welcome back to another blog about artificial intelligence. In case you are a new reader you should definately read the previous blog too about chatGPT, the AI chatbot! You can read it here. Where chatGPT is a chatbot, Dall-E is a digital artisan. By giving it a description of which image you want, Dall-E generates a couple of images for you and I must admit that the results are pretty whopping.

item.title: Hello my name Is Chatgpt!
item.description: Technology is something that is constantly evolving. When you take a look at Gartner’s hypecycle you can see a curve that shows you which technologies are coming our way. You will see a couple of different topics regarding AI, and that’s where todays post is talking about. A big name in this artificial intelligence space is OpenAI thanks to it’s 2 big projects that you can recognize by the names of:

item.title: My 3D Printing Setup and settings
item.description: Often questions are asked about how I do my 3D prints. 3D Printing is a hobby that’s getting picked up by a broader audience at this point. The main reason for this according to my humble self is the current pricepoint to start with. You can have a decent 3D printer for about 200 euro, this can give you already some decent results and it gets even better when you perform some basic upgrades.

item.title: Subatomic a game about cool physics and chemistry!
item.description: A cool thing about playing boardgames is that from time to time you can really learn something. In Subatomic you can learn a lot about cool physics and chemistry! This game is a game that I backed on Kickstarter a couple of years ago and has been played a couple of times with my kids back in the day. The coolest thing about this is that I have a numbered edition, I have 224 out of 3400!

item.title: Sonos on a different vlan using the Unifi USG
item.description: Lately, I have been doing some changes on my home network that involved vlanning. Of course, when you say vlan & Sonos in one sentence you’ve got to make ready for some issues. You can find my lessons learned in this blog. I can tell you that it wasn’t easy to overcome this. Situation My network looks a little bit like this: Vlan: Internet of things Vlan: End user devices Lan with all the Unifi devices I’m using a Unifi Cloudkey Gen2 plus as my Unifi controller.

item.title: Streamdeck Installation on Linux
item.description: Nowadays streaming is a widely practiced hobby. Gaming, e-sports, etc… are all things that aid to the popularity of streaming as a whole. A lot of people dream about streaming content for a living and for that you need to have a setup that enables you to do a lot of different stuff on stream, there comes the Streamdeck into play. The Streamdeck is actually a buttonbox that you can program with all kinds of functionality to enhance your streams or even you worklife.

item.title: This blog costs less then 10$ per year
item.description: Yes, it is possible. You can run a website for virtually no money thanks to a couple of software and services. Actually, you don’t need a full fledged CMS for a personal website. A CMS is the abbreviation of a content management system and is a website that’s built around a database and forms to add content to the website. This means a lot of code that can be abused by not so friendly visitors.

item.title: Welcome to John's two cents
item.description: Hi, After some years of absence in the blog-o-sphere, I decided to start writing again. After running a successfull blog for quite some time I was ready to take some time off as running the blog was too time-consuming. I had the joy back then to organize Blogosphere, a meetup for Belgian bloggers, work with PR agencies and attend different press events. I guess I did all what I wanted to achieve back in the day.
